# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # Filter for Audi A4 and A4 quattro
    df_filtered = df_cars[
        df_cars.manufacturer .== "audi",
        :model => ByRow(x -> x == "a4" || x == "a4 quattro"),
    ]
    # Add new column indicating Audi A4 type
    df_filtered[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df_filtered
end
```
This function assumes that `manufacturer` and `model` are already categorical variables in the provided DataFrame `df_cars`. If they are not, you may need to convert them using something like:

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # Convert columns to categorical if not already
    df_cars = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df_cars; cols=:manufacturer) |>
        transform(model => ByRow((x) -> x == "a4" || x == "a4 quattro") => :is_a4_quattro!, renamecols=false)
    # Add new column indicating Audi A4 type
    df_cars[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df_cars
end
```

The function above will filter the DataFrame based on the `manufacturer` and `model` columns, then add a new column `audi_a4_type` that is `true` for all rows. Note that this function assumes that the `df_cars` DataFrame has columns named `manufacturer` and `model`, and that it contains at least one row with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro".
